poem:
### Butterfly Effect

In the dragon's breath, a flap of wings,
not simple, nor better. George's curse sings.
A fluttered shift, plots intertwine,
larger, more toxic, down the line.

Characters tangle in nets we wove,
depths of oceans, heights of grove.
Steel meets parchment, ink-stained shift,
stories unchained, adrift, adrift.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Simpler is not better’: George RR Martin blasts House of the Dragon over plot changes George RR Martin has criticised the second season of House of the Dragon over changes to his plot that he says he “argued against” due to a butterfly effect, warning: “There are larger and more toxic butterflies to come.” Martin, the author of the bestselling Game of Thrones books and the prequel Fire & Blood, on which House of the". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
